facts.text: Writ Petition No. 111 of 1969 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 111 of 1969. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the court was delivered by Sikri, J. This is a joint petition by two detenues under art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Joint petition by two detenues Arshad Ahmad and Fazal Hussain praying for release via habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: This is a joint petition by two detenues under art. 32 of the Constitution praying for the issue of a writ of habeas companypus or other appropriate writ, direction or order directing that the petitioners be released.

facts.text: Arshad Ahmad detained pursuant to Detention Order dated September 19, 1967 under s. 3(1)(a)(i) of the Jammu Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Arshad Ahmad, was detained in pursuance of Detention Order dated September 19, 1967, passed under s. 3 1  a  i  of the Jammu Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

facts.text: Detention order served on Arshad Ahmad by Jaswant Singh, Deputy Superintendent of Police CID, Jammu on September 27, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the order on the record shows that the order was served on the detenu by Jaswant Singh, Deputy Superintendent of Police  CID , Jammu on September 27, 1967.

facts.text: No grounds of detention were served on Arshad Ahmad.

anchor.surface_text: No grounds of detention were served on the detenu, but an order dated October 25, 1967, issued by the Secretary to the Government, Home Department, was served on him

facts.text: Order dated October 25, 1967 issued by Secretary to the Government, Home Department served on Arshad Ahmad informing against public interest to disclose grounds.

anchor.surface_text: but an order dated October 25, 1967, issued by the Secretary to the Government, Home Department, was served on him informing him that it would be against the public interest to disclose the facts or the grounds of detention to him.

facts.text: Petitioner contends that order dated October 25, 1967 was served too late making detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Garg, contends that the order dated October 25, 1967, was served too late and the detention of the petitioner became illegal when the time for serving the grounds of detention had expired.

facts.text: Section 8 of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964 requires grounds communicated within 10 days of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964, provides that when a person is detained in pursuance of a detention order, the authority making the order shall, as soon as may be, but not later than ten days from the date of detention, communicate to him the grounds on which the order has been made,

facts.text: Proviso to s.8 allows authority to direct that grounds not communicated if against public interest for security of State.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that nothing in this sub- section shall apply to the case of any person detained with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State, if the authority making the order, by the same or a subsequent order, directs that the person detained may be informed that it would be against public interest to communicate to him the grounds on which the detention order has been made.

facts.text: Respondent contends that order under proviso can be made beyond 10 days.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the State contends that if an order has been made under the proviso it does not matter whether the order is made and served beyond the ten days time specified in

facts.text: Court holds detention of Arshad Ahmad illegal because proviso order served after 10 days.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released.

facts.text: Fazal Hussain detained by order dated January 3, 1968 under s.3(1) read with s.5 of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the case of the second petitioner Fazal Hussain, he was detained by order dated January 3, 1968, passed under  1  1957 S.C.R. 51, 59. s. 3 1  read with s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

facts.text: Detention order served on Fazal Hussain in Central Jail on January 8, 1968 and read out to him.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was served on the petitioner in the Central Jail on January 8, 1968, and the same was read out to him.

facts.text: Order dated January 11, 1968 informed Fazal Hussain that against public interest to disclose grounds.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated January 11, 1968, the petitioner was informed that it was against public interest to disclose facts or to communicate to him the grounds on which the detention order was passed.

facts.text: Affidavit sworn by Additional Secretary to Government, Jammu and Kashmir, Home Department stating facts based on record.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit stating these facts is sworn to by the Additional Secretary to the Government, Jammu and Kashmir, Home Department, and it is stated in the verification that these facts were stated on the basis of information derived from the record of the case which he believed to be true.

facts.text: Petitioner contends Deputy Superintendent Central Jail should have filed affidavit for service.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the petitioner contends that the Deputy Superintendent Central Jail, who is alleged to have served the order of detention on the petitioner, should have filed the affidavit.

facts.text: Endorsement on detention order: notice served upon Fazal Hussain by reading over by Dy. Superintendent Central Jail, Jammu on 8/1.

anchor.surface_text: The State has annexed to the affidavit a copy of the Government Detention Order and below the detention order the following endorsement exists The notice of this order has been served upon Shri Fazal Hussain s o Ayub Khan detenu by reading over the same to him. Sd -Dy. Superintendent Central Jail, Jammu 8/1

facts.text: Court holds no need for affidavit from Deputy Superintendent Central Jail due to endorsement.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this endorsement the order of detention we do not consider that it was necessary that the Deputy Superintendent, Central Jail, should have filed an affidavit to the effect that he had served the order of detention on the detenu Fazal Hussain.

facts.text: Petition of Fazal Hussain dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of Fazal Hussain accordingly fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Counsel for petitioners: K. Garg and Anil Kumar Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: K. Garg and Anil Kumar Gupta for the petitioners.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: Gopalakrishnan and R.N. Sachthey.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan and R.N. Sachthey, for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companytention. There is numberdoubt that it is the duty of the detaining authority to companymunicate the grounds within ten days of the date of detention if the case does number fall within the proviso. If the detaining authority neither companymunicates the grounds of detention number informs the detenu under the proviso within 10 days of the detention, the detention would become illegal and a subsequent order under the proviso would number have the effect of rendering the detention legal.

arguments.claim: Similar provisions require declaration under proviso before expiry of time to prevent illegal detention as per Abdul Jabar Butt precedent

anchor.surface_text: A similar point arose before this Court in Abdul Jabar Butt v. State of Jammu Kashmir 1 . This Court was then companysidering the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act  IV of Sambat 2011  and similar provisions companytained therein. Das, C.J., observed If the grounds are number companymunicated to the detenu within the period of time prescribed by the expression as soon as may be the detenu becomes deprived of his statutory right under sub-s.  1  and his detention in such circumstances becomes illegal as being otherwise than in accordance with procedure prescribed by law.

arguments.claim: Power under proviso must be exercised before the result of sub-s.(1) sets in, consistent with harmonious construction

anchor.surface_text: In order to prevent this result in a certain specified cases the proviso authorises the Government to issue the requisite declaration so as to exclude entirely the operation of sub-s.  1 . It, therefore, stands to reason and is companysistent with the principle of harmonious companystruction of statutes that the power of issuing a declaration so as to prevent the unwanted result of the operation of sub-s.  1  should be exercised before that very result sets in.

arguments.claim: Construction protecting liberty of subject; government has ample time within 10 days to decide on proviso

anchor.surface_text: We. are here companycerned with the liberty of a subject and we must adopt a companystruction which would number have the effect of enabling the executive to make an order under the proviso at any time after the lapse of ten days specified in s. 8. Even from the practical point of view we are unable to. see that the Government would experience any difficulty in deciding within ten days whether the grounds should be served or number in the public interest.

holdings.text: If the detaining authority neither communicates the grounds of detention nor informs the detenu under the proviso within 10 days of the detention, the detention would become illegal and a subsequent order under the proviso would not have the effect of rendering the detention legal.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. There is no doubt that it is the duty of the detaining authority to communicate the grounds within ten days of the date of detention if the case does not fall within the proviso. If the detaining authority neither communicates the grounds of detention nor informs the detenu under the proviso within 10 days of the detention, the detention would become illegal and a subsequent order under the proviso would not have the effect of rendering the detention legal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detaining authority must act within 10 days to comply with s.8 or invoke proviso; failure renders detention illegal per procedure prescribed by law; supported by precedent in Abdul Jabar Butt and harmonious construction.

holdings.text: In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso order served on Oct 25, 1967 after 10 days from Sept 19, 1967 detention; no grounds served timely; applies rule that late proviso invocation does not cure illegality.

holdings.text: In view of this endorsement the order of detention we do not consider that it was necessary that the Deputy Superintendent, Central Jail, should have filed an affidavit to the effect that he had served the order of detention on the detenu Fazal Hussain.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this endorsement the order of detention we do not consider that it was necessary that the Deputy Superintendent, Central Jail, should have filed an affidavit to the effect that he had served the order of detention on the detenu Fazal Hussain.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsement on detention order by Dy. Superintendent proves service by reading out; affidavit from Additional Secretary based on records sufficient.

holdings.text: The petition of Fazal Hussain accordingly fails and is dismissed.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Jabar Butt v. State of Jammu Kashmir
precedents.cited_proposition: The declaration under the proviso excluding communication of grounds must be issued before the expiry of the time limit for communicating grounds (ten days), otherwise the detention becomes illegal as the detenu is deprived of the statutory right.
precedents.cited_holding: If the grounds are number companymunicated to the detenu within the period of time prescribed by the expression as soon as may be the detenu becomes deprived of his statutory right under sub-s. 1 and his detention in such circumstances becomes illegal as being otherwise than in accordance with procedure prescribed by law. In order to prevent this result... the power of issuing a declaration... should be exercised before that very result sets in.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released. Coming to the case of the second petitioner Fazal Hussain, he was detained by order dated January 3, 1968, passed under  1  1957 S.C.R. 51, 59. s. 3 1  read with s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964. The order of detention was served on the petitioner in the Central Jail on January 8, 1968, and the same was read out to him. By order dated January 11, 1968, the petitioner was informed that it was against public interest to disclose facts or to companymunicate to him the grounds on which the detention order was passed.

outcome.relief_summary: Detention of first petitioner Arshad Ahmad declared illegal and he is directed to be released; petition of second petitioner Fazal Hussain dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. There is no doubt that it is the duty of the detaining authority to communicate the grounds within ten days of the date of detention if the case does not fall within the proviso. If the detaining authority neither communicates the grounds of detention nor informs the detenu under the proviso within 10 days of the detention, the detention would become illegal and a subsequent order under the proviso would not have the effect of rendering the detention legal.

In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released. Coming to the case of the second petitioner Fazal Hussain, he was detained by order dated January 3, 1968, passed under  1  1957 S.C.R. 51, 59. s. 3 1  read with s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964. The order of detention was served on the petitioner in the Central Jail on January 8, 1968, and the same was read out to him. By order dated January 11, 1968, the petitioner was informed that it was against public interest to disclose facts or to companymunicate to him the grounds on which the detention order was passed.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this endorsement the order of detention we do not consider that it was necessary that the Deputy Superintendent, Central Jail, should have filed an affidavit to the effect that he had served the order of detention on the detenu Fazal Hussain.

In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released. Coming to the case of the second petitioner Fazal Hussain, he was detained by order dated January 3, 1968, passed under  1  1957 S.C.R. 51, 59. s. 3 1  read with s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964. The order of detention was served on the petitioner in the Central Jail on January 8, 1968, and the same was read out to him. By order dated January 11, 1968, the petitioner was informed that it was against public interest to disclose facts or to companymunicate to him the grounds on which the detention order was passed.
The petition of Fazal Hussain accordingly fails and is dismissed.

In the result we hold that the detention of the petitioner Arshad Ahmad is illegal and he should be released. The order of detention was served on the petitioner in the Central Jail on January 8, 1968, and the same was read out to him. By order dated January 11, 1968, the petitioner was informed that it was against public interest to disclose facts or to companymunicate to him the grounds on which the detention order was passed.
